div.p: In RPGs, most gameplay does not need rules. During play, players will only recurr to rules in two instances:

ul.li: The gameworld is alien enough that common sense cannot be used to resolve a situation. This is the case for magic spell casting, for instance.

Players and GMs do not want to determine the outcome according to their common understanding but want some undeterministic influence, i.e. chance, to do it for them. This may be used to enhance tension or drama but also to reolve different understanding of the situation by different players, but they can still agree on a chance value.

div.p: Additionally, common rule systems create probabilities that are hard to gauge. In fact, only for playing a game for an extended period of time, will patterns emerge. I find this fatiguing, in particular, if the probabilities do not turn out to match expectations and thereby impact enjoyment.
The following rules are written with these points in mind.

ul.li: Keep out rules that explain a setting. Let's call these in-world rules. Rules are called out-world rules, when they apply only to players and/or the GM. Sometimes the distinction is not easy, a matter of taste, or how willing you are to distinguish.
Keep it comprehensible. This does not mean generic simple, but rather that probabilities do not provide surprises when subject matter changes.

div.p: The following section contains a few reasonable assumptions on rules and tries to explain, why certain rules are chosen. If you are only interested in the mechanics, you can skip it.

Most rules intend to resolve skill application. Whether it be fighting, hiding, finding, lifting, or something else. A character can have different skill levels but tasks at hand can also also have different difficulty levels. We make the following assumptions: A skill proficiency and a task difficulty can be expressed as numbers. A skill level of k has the same chance of success for one task of difficulty n and one of difficulty m, as a skill of k against a single task of difficulty of n+m. The numbers m, n, k are your regular (integer) numbers. A skill level of k has the same chance of success for one task of difficulty n as a skill of level n has of failure against a task of difficulty k. Assuming we have a failure probability of p/2 for a skill of 1 for a task of 0, we will restrict ourselves to p=0.8.

The only real assumptions are set in bold. This is in fact all we need, because the following are conclusions. This paragraph was written to show that we make very few, natural assumptions that already imply the most important rule.

p.em: You roll a d5 until you roll a 1 and then count the number of dice that did not show up a 1. That is the same as the number of dice you actually rolled minus one. The higher you get, the better. This first number is used for the active character, or more generally, the actor. It should be clear in almost all situations, who is active - the one with the applicable skill. We call it the positive (stop) roll roll, even though it is a number of rolls. Of course, there is a negative (stop) roll that is associated with the passive resistance or impediment, which is handled in the same way. That would be the task in most cases. The result of the negative stop roll (which is still a positive number!) is subtracted from the result of the positive. Understanding this rule is crucial, so we elaborate by listing the probabilities involved as well as some examples.

div.p: The mechanism is different from most other rules (I haven't found any that use it), where you will often roll either a pool of dice and count those that match a certain threshold or single die roll.

All these methods, ours included, are usually compared against a threshold. The further away from the threshold you are the more extreme the results will become. Depending of the sign of the difference, the results is good or bad for the actor.

The follwoing two tables are explanatory and not needed, just as the Translation section. The mechanics have been described completely in the highlighted section. Everything else can be used to reduce the number of dice thrown or to better understand the implication of the (stop) roll mechanic.

In Table 1 the first row shows the results you can achieve when making a positive roll. Since you continue rolling until you get a 1 on your d5, you can interpret the complete positive stop roll as a series of d5 rolls as you move right on the first row, starting with 0. The second row shows the chance that you have of moving up one point (i.e. right) at any given point. Note that this chance is always the same. The third row gives the percentage chance that you have of achieving the result in the corresponding first row. These you could achieve by rolling a d100 in order to cut down on the number of dice to roll. All but the first column of this row are approximations.

The last column is somewhat special. It combines all higher results. You could expand the table to infinity, if you wanted. While the extensions of the first and second row are quite obvious, the third is not. It should be interpreted thus: if you roll 91-100, i.e. the highest 10%, you need to roll again on this table, get the result as before and then add 10 to the result. (For the mathematically inclined, this is a recursive definition, since it is possible that you roll 91-100 again, which forces you to roll on this table again and add 20 to the net result from the repeated application. We will see this in the examples.) Some system have a similar mechanic and call it an "exploding" roll or "open-ended".

The previous table only considered one stop roll, either the positive or the negative. (You can also call them the active and the passive (stop) roll; in most instances the obstacle is passive, such as door being lock-picked or a weight being lifted.) The following table shows the chances for overall results. Generally, the next table is interpreted as the one above, with only a few key differences.

With a roll of 01-06 and 95-100 the extended roll is continued on the previous table with certain consequences. Positive continuation - the one on the right end of the table with 95-100 - is exactly as before, while negative continuation results in negative results to be added. For instance, rolling 02 and then a 25 gives a result of -11. The second row cell below the 0 result means 4/9 chance to increase the result by 1, the same chance to descrease the result by one and a 1/9 to stay at 0. The astute reader will see the chance for 0 in the third row is only 8%, while 1/9 is approximatly 11%. Again this is due to rounding; the price for rolling less dice.
In case a more precise outcome needs to be rolled, roll a d10 for as many digits after the decimal point as needed.

The most generic way to roll the dice would be to roll d5 until a 1 is rolled. To improve speed, several d10s may be rolled in ordered fashion. Order them according to size or alphabetical color (e.g. black, blue, green, yellow) or in any other way you can remember. With a d10 stop at 1 or 2. If you lack d5s, you can also roll d6s with only a marginal 3% error on each roll. But all players (and GM) should roll the same type dice. Computer applications that make rolling as easy as pressing a button are also easy to program.

Assume you decided to use d100 and rolled a 24 on the first roll. This means a result of 1 on the first table. The second roll (the negative or passive roll) shows a 50, which results in 3 for a net result of -2.
Using Table 2, a 28 is rolled, which results in -3.

A more exotic roll would be the sequence 96, 99, 93, 61 on the d100. The result would be 34 for a positive stop roll. For a combined stop roll, the result would be 29 (and the roll of 61 ignored, because it is not needed, because the 93 already "stops" on Table 2).

Using the standard method, the positive sequence on a d10 shows 3, 8, 10, 7, 9, 4, 6, 3, 10, 10, 8, 4, 2 and the negative sequence shows 3, 6, 9, 4, 4, 1. The result is positive 12 and negative 5 with a net result of +7.
If you decide that +7 is not precise enough, a roll of 3 and 5 on a d10 (each) gives are finer result of +7.35. I.e. you simple roll the decimal places.
Remember that the second row is technically correct and the third row only provides less rolls. We will look at some further hints for rolling.

Active and passive are symmetrical. If you imagine one character stealthily evading another, the first may interprete the rolls as his actively evading against a passive observation of the surroundings, while the second may interprete the rolls as his actively scrutinzing the vicinity against a passively hiding opponent. Either way, one roll (or set of rolls) will determine the outcome.

When describing a certain situation, the actor and the obstacle both possess a ceratin level. The first is usually a skill in the particular act and second a measure of the difficulty of the task. In the previous example, the observer might have a (skill) level of 5 and finding the clandestine character a (task) level of 3. These levels will be added to the positive and negative stop rolls, respectively.

We are adding and subtracting 4 numbers; stop rolls and levels. The calculations result in a level difference between the active and the passive part (or the skill level and task level) which is relevant for rolling. If only the failure or success is of interest and not the degree of success or failure, you can apply the following shortcut. Since the difference must be met by the lower level contestant, you may roll all the difference dice in one combined “throw” and check, whether any stop digit appears. If it does the lower contestant cannot win, since it is irrelevant, where the stop digit appears. If the stop digit does not appear, chances have reduced to 50/50, and you can flip a coin in any of a number of ways.

For example, suppose the active climber with a skill level of 57 wants to scale a cliff of difficulty level 49. The difference is 8. The GM rolls 8 dice, which show up 3, 5, 6, 1, 3, 9, 9, and 8. Since 1 is a stop digit, the cliff is scaled. If the 1 had been a 7 instead, for instance, the cliff would have had a "fighting chance" to drop the character. The GM decides that even is good for the character and odd is bad and rolls a d10. It comes up a 6 and the character has barely made it. Any story-telling description of this close encounter is at your option.

Another pragmatic rule applies to differences of at least 10. Rolling 10 non-stop rolls in a row to match a level difference of 10 can be shortened to rolling a 1 on a d10. The chance 1/10 is an approximation of 0.1073741824, which is the exact chance. In fact, the choice of d5 in the initial paragraph was made for the reason that this heuristic holds.

Many rulesets rank a skill on a percentile scale 0% through 100%. This is the case for Rolemaster, Runequest, or Harnmaster. Rolling below your skill value makes you succeed. This approximates our levels 0, 10, 20 and 30 at about the classical 5%, 35%, 65%, and 95%. That means these rules have about fourty skill levels, in which all values fall according to our rules. The same is true for Dungeons and Dragons, Pathfinder, or generally the d20 group of rules, which use twenty 5% steps, instead of the finer grained 1% step. Note that these steps are approximations, since none of these rolls are translation-invariant.

Note that you could just multiply the d20 skill levels by two or take half for the precentile system, why the strange, non-linear mapping? Since we do not intend to simulate other rules in this manner, you most certainly can do that conversion. We provide the above to show that the

The two-page character sheet is applicable to all rules, because it captures the out-world probabilities. You need to fill in the relevant skills and tasks for the PC. Since the possible combinations are virtually limitless, list only the most common ones or add another sheet, if you do not find a suitable decomposition of skills and tasks.
Most rules apply linear modifications (i.e. additions and subtractions) to the skill and task levels and this is what we do for specific rule conversions in the dedicated sections.
All following headings are links to the corresponding sub-pages.

The following rules address common situations. How do you combine a group of actors that support each other? How do you apply two skills to a task that fits both? You should never indiscriminately add values. Remember that a difference of 10 means a 90% winning difference by design.
Taking the best skill roll of two (this is the same as requiring at least one of the two to succeed) can be done by using the table below.

Say you want to add the skills n and m of two actors, where the respective task difficulties have already been subtracted. In the first row, you index the positive difference between n and m. The second row will then give you the "bonus" to add to the higher of the two skills - which is then the only one you need to roll. Say the skills are 5 and 9. Then the net skill level of the two actors together is 12.

The rule can be applied multiple times and its application does not depend on the order or sub-grouping of several actors. In order to keep this rule simple, round results in your tables. If you use the rule multiple times, always group two actors of similar skill levels together to reduce rounding errors. (This is "normalized" skill level, i.e. the task level has already been subtracted.)

As a more elaborate example, say you have four characters in a room searching for something and you have determined that this technically means that either of those characters could find it, i.e. all would have to roll against a set diffculty. But you want just one roll. These characters have a skill level of 5, 7, 13, and 17. Taking the first two, because they are closest to each other, we combine them into an actor with 11. Now we combine 11 and 13 in the same manner to 17. In the last step, we combine 17 and 17 into 22.

If you have two actors that both must succeed a test, that is equivalent to using the reverse stop roll, which means exchanging the role of positive and negative for the purposes of combining. Logically this means that either obstacle may foil the actor. Keep in mind that the reversal of positive and negative roll also changes who of the two has the higher skill level.

Imagine in the previous example that the same characters are trying to hide from a guard. If one is detected, the guard will raise the alarm and the maneuver fails. As luck will have it, their Hide skill level is exactly as their Search skill level. But now it is passive: 5 and 7 will turn into 1. 13 and 17 (closest together) will turn into 10. The difficulty of the skill "pairs" 1 and 10 turns into -1. Since the guard isn't really paying attention, the GM gives the guard a skill level of 0. That leaves the group with a 60% failure chance.

If you are worried about rounding errors, use the following formula, where β is the difference in level you plug in and and the addition to the higher value is calculated. Round when done with "addition".

Do not be overwhelmed by this suggestion, you will most likely never ever use it, since role playing is more about an individual's actions than a group's. And lengthy calculations just to be correct will reduce enjoyment. Use it only when players try to "break the rules" by misconstrued rounding and then have them do the math! Come to think of it, players never do that, so forget the whole suggestion.

A skill may be decomposed into other skills, if so desired. The decomposition must be such that the combination of (weighted) averages of the new skill levels results in the original skill level. Additional measures should be in place to indicate that the skills actually belong to a group. A typical restriction is that the individual skills of a goup may not differ by more than 10 points.

If a decomposition results in multiple rolls, make sure that the rules of Combinations remain valid. A typical example would be to turn a roll that would usually apply every 10 days into a roll that applies every day. This implies that all of the daily rolls have a difficulty increased by 10.

Decomposition and then combining skills is a great tool to extend the skill space beyond what rules generally cover. Imagine that a PC wants to tie a knot, but his skill sheet says he has level 5 as Sailor and level 3 as Mountaineer. For tasks like knots where the difficulty is the same for a Sailor and a Mountaineer, the GM can allow the PC to use a 9. The reasoning is that the knot skill application works as if two separate actors were trying to tie the knot together. Be careful, however, with allowing such additions, because if you treat 0 as the value an untrained individual has, then in the above case a sailor that has never seen a mountain would still have a 0 in mountaeineering and adding a 0 would yield an effective knot skill of 8.
